text:
$$
        \sum_{r+s+t=n}(-1)^{rs+t}f_{r+1+t}(id^{\otimes r} \otimes m_{s} \otimes id^{\otimes t})
      = \sum_{\substack{1\leq p \leq n \\ i_{1}+\cdots+i_{p}=n}} (-1)^{\omega}m_{p}(f_{i_{1}} \otimes \cdots \otimes f_{i_{p}}),
      $$

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\sum_{r+s+t=n}(-1)^{rs+t}f_{r+1+t}(id^{\otimes r}\otimes m_{s}\otimes id^{%
\otimes t})=\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}1\leq p\leq n\\
i_{1}+\cdots+i_{p}=n\end{subarray}}(-1)^{\omega}m_{p}(f_{i_{1}}\otimes\cdots%

text: $$ d_{BA}  \otimes id_{A} + id_{BA} \otimes d_{A} + (id_{BA} \otimes \mu)(id_{BA} \otimes \pi \otimes id_{A})(\Delta_{BA} \otimes id_{A}),$$

nexttext: Take $(a_{1},r,a_{2},\ldots,a_{n}) \in A^{\otimes_{k} (n+1)} $ into above identity. All terms on the left hand side of the above identity vanish except $ m_{n}(m_{2} \otimes_{k} id^{\otimes_{k} (n-1)}) $ and $m_{n}(id \otimes_{k} m_{2} \otimes_{k} id^{\otimes_{k} (n-2)})$. Thus the desired identity

2<s<n-1\end{subarray}}(-1)^{rs+t}m_{r+1+t}(id^{\otimes r}\otimes_{k}m_{s}%

prevtext: Take $(a_{1},r,a_{2},\ldots,a_{n}) \in A^{\otimes_{k} (n+1)} $ into above identity. All terms on the left hand side of the above identity vanish except $ m_{n}(m_{2} \otimes_{k} id^{\otimes_{k} (n-1)}) $ and $m_{n}(id \otimes_{k} m_{2} \otimes_{k} id^{\otimes_{k} (n-2)})$. Thus the desired identity

nexttext:
with $P/A \cong (V \otimes_{R} U)[1]$ in the homotopy category of right dg module over $U$. This implies that $p\emph{dim} R < \infty$. Dually by \cite[Theorem 3.2.c]{Keller1994}, one can show that $i\emph{dim} R < \infty$.

    We view $U$ as an augmented $A_{\infty}$-algebra over $kQ_{0}$ and take a minimal model $H(U)$ of $U$. For convenience, we make the following convention.
    We use $\mathcal{D}(U)$ to denote the derived category of right dg modules over $U$, and $Loc(R)$ ($resp$. $Loc_{\infty}(R)$, $Loc_{\infty}(R_{H(U)})$) the the smallest triangulated subcategory of $\mathcal{D}(U)$ ($resp$. $\mathcal{D}_{\infty}(U)$, $\mathcal{D}_{\infty}(H(U))$) closed under arbitrary direct sums and containing $R$.

    It remains to show that $D(U) \in Loc(R)$. Since $A$ is a dg algebra and $H(U)$ is a minimal model of $U$, by Proposition \ref{p2.2}, there is a triangulated equivalence between $\mathcal{D}(U)$ and $D_{\infty}(H(U))$ which induces a triangulated equivalence between $Loc(R)$ and $Loc_{\infty}(R_{H(U)})$. To show $D(U) \in Loc(R)$ is equivalent to show that $D(U)$, which is viewed as an right $A_{\infty}$-module over $H(U)$, belongs to $Loc_{\infty}(R_{H(U)})$.

    By \cite[Proposition 3.3.1.7]{Lefevre-Hasegawa2003}, let $(H(D(U)), m_{2},m_{3},\ldots)$ be a minimal model of $D(U)$ as right $A_{\infty}$-module over $H(U)$. Since $H(D(U))$ is isomorphic to $D(kQ)$ as graded $k$-vector spaces, $H(D(U))$ is concentrated in nonpositive degrees. Note that $m_{n}$ is of degree $2-n$ for $n \geq 2$, it is easy to see $H(D(U))$ admits a filtration of $A_{\infty}$-submodules $\{F_{p}\}$ for $p \geq 0$ defined as follow: $F_{0}= D(R) \cong R$, $F_{p}=\bigoplus_{n\ge -p} H(D(A))^n$ for $p > 0$. By construction $F_{p+1}/F_{p}$ is concentrated in degree $-p-1$ for $p \geq 0$. Therefore $F_{p+1}/F_{p} \in \mathrm{Add}(R)$ and there is a series of  exact sequences of $A_{\infty}$-modules

such that $P/U \cong (V \otimes_{R} U)[1]$. We mention that in Keller's construction (see \cite[Theorem 3.2.c]{Keller1994}) one can choose $P$ to be an $R$-bimodule and all morphisms in the above triangle to be homomorphisms of $R$-bimodules. By definition $E(U)=\mathcal{E}nd_{U}(P)$.
